p: A different problem was investigated by Silva et al. [ 18]. The authors looked for the effective compounds against mosquito Aedes aegypti, which is the vector for arboviral diseases (dengue, Zika, yellow fever, and chikungunya). They tested the Connarus suberosus (a species common in the Cerrado biome in Brazil) root wood ethyl acetate extract and 28 compounds from the quinone class for development of a larvicide. Embelin and rapanone, isolated from the plant extract, were active against mosquito third-instar larvae. Eight quinones demonstrated larvicidal activity. Tectoquinone was the most active compound and was selected for formulation trials to develop a non-toxic prototype larvicide to control the mosquito development.
